title: Riot logic: Giving leavers LP penalty messes up system (DELETED TWICE CAUSE OF TRUTH)

embed.description: Matchmaking Guide League of Legends uses a mathematical system to match up players of similar skill in the "Normal" and "Ranked" game types. The basic priorities of the system are (in respective order): Protect new players Create fair and competitive matches Make games less toxic by matching you with the right players The system will extend queue times over sacrificing accuracy, which is why challenger players may face much longer queue times than the average player.

body:
I am unsure if the moderator thought i was negative, but I wasn't if they actually read my post.
My previous post got deleted
This time I will try to be as factual as possible
Everything I say is intended for **Ranked play** only


Riot does not give an LP punishment to leavers.(aside from normal loss)

Leavers Gain MMR if their Team wins even if they have contributed NOTHING to the game

"If your team wins, you will gain points; if your team loses, you will lose points. Whether you are in the game at the end is irrelevant to this outcome.
If we gave you a penalty even if they won, we would be "deflating" the entire system of ratings over time, causing new players to possibly run into professional players eventually."

^that will never happen, unless pros just decide to frequently leave all the time, like its acceptable or something

Also I think being in the game at the end can be pretty relevant to an outcome.

I would also rally for a ban system in which there is a zero tolerance policy on ranked leavers.
This would include a very light slap on the wrist 30 minute ban for first time offense, and steeply go up in duration to say a max of maybe two weeks from ranked play if someone repeatedly leaves ranked. (keep in mind they will still be able to play normals)
If a user plays some agreed number  of games (maybe 10-20 ranked games w/o leaving) then their punishment should go back down to that of a first offender.

A fix to the report system is needed too. Riot should limit the # of reports a player has based on the number of games they have played, so everyone cant just report everyone. 
Also Riot should punish false reports.
Limiting report number, and punishing false reports will increase report quality.

Another solution to toxic players should be a sub forum similar to the tribunal in which summoners post screenshots or chat logs of very toxic players they have played with. (must have evidence)
This will relieve many frustrations people have when playing with a severe troll, and give them a sense of accomplishment and relief knowing that the extreme toxic will most likely get banned.
There have been several occasions where I have opened a riot support ticket just because i got extremely trolled.
A rioter, should then browse this subforum with a ban hammer, banning these accounts or restricting them after one last official review.

I have played this game for god damn 5 years and I WILL NOT BE SILENCED

If we gave you a penalty even if they won, we would be "deflating" the entire system of ratings over time, causing new players to possibly run into professional players eventually."

Maybe you shouldn't post angry, accusatory posts if you don't understand the system.

MMR is an an "Elo-like" rating system.  These types of rating systems require that ranking gains and losses be balanced -- for one person to go up in rank, someone else has to go down.

Consider a game where a 4v5 team wins (or where a player is absent for a while, then comes back and they manage to win).  The losing team loses MMR, the winning team gains MMR.  If the player who left *also* loses MMR, then 6 players lost rating and only 4 gained rating.  Over time this would "deflate" ratings, which causes all kinds of weird problems with the Ranked ladder.
So why not give those lost MMR points to the other players? If you win 4v5, you gain more MMR than if you win 5v5, with the difference paid by the leaver?
You might be able to make something like this work.  Since Riot doesn't release a ton of details about the internals of their ranking system, I couldn't say for sure.

But it shouldn't work like this.
MMR is an indicator of your skill, it shouldn't depend on wins or losses.
At the end of the game, if you played well, you get MMR, if you played bad, you lose MMR.
If you won the game, you get LP, if you lost the game, you lose LP.
MMR and LP should be calculated separately. Simple as that.

>MMR is an indicator of your skill, it shouldn't depend on wins or losses.

Given that the objective of the game is to win, somewhat by definition the "skill" they're trying to measure in solo queue is how likely it is that a team you are on will win.

>At the end of the game, if you played well, you get MMR, if you played bad, you lose MMR.

Please define "played well" and "played bad[ly]" in a way that wouldn't horribly distort gameplay or completely cement the meta and stunt the potential development of new strategies.

>If you won the game, you get LP, if you lost the game, you lose LP.

The problem with this is that streaky players will bounce around wildly from division to division even if they haven't actually changed their level of skill very much.

> Given that the objective of the game is to win, somewhat by definition the "skill" they're trying to measure in solo queue is how likely it is that a team you are on will win.

That definition actually would qualify well for team ranked. In solo queue the system has to judge you and your level of skill and the ability you have to help your team to win. But in a game there are 10 people, you make up for only 10% of it. You may be able to win under certain conditions. If you had another team, you could have won, you never know that. The system should be impartial and calculate only your 10% of impact in game, not the overall.
> Please define "played well" and "played bad[ly]" in a way that wouldn't horribly distort gameplay or completely cement the meta and stunt the potential development of new strategies.

There could be damage to champions and minions, damage / time spent autoattacking structures, damage to dragon / baron, overall time your wards revealed an otherwise fogged place.
And then there are personal champ mechanics and ability to fight opponent's mechanics, but these would be very difficult to calculate.
> The problem with this is that streaky players will bounce around wildly from division to division even if they haven't actually changed their level of skill very much.

Actually I described the actual system. At the moment if you lose you lose lp and if you win you win lp. So I didn't get your point. XD

>That definition actually would qualify well for team ranked.

I'm not sure I am explaining what I mean properly.  At a really rough level you might say that your expected performance is due to two things: how well you play personally, and how well the rest of your team plays.  In ranked 5s there is only one factor, because they rate the **team** and not the individual players.  Over a large number of matches the contributions of the other players even out - but of course it can be frustrating in the short term.

It's very attractive in theory to say that Riot should apportion the blame for wins and losses onto individuals.  But: 

1. This is **very** hard to do in any but the coarsest ways.  "Good" deaths are very hard to account for.  Vision contributions are very hard to assign properly.
2. It's **very** easy to "play for stats" in some cases, and some roles/champs innately have a much easier time racking up impressive stats.  Tanks and supports in particular don't get the same KDAs, CS numbers, damage done, objective kills, etc.
3. In other cases (particularly when you're behind) it can create perverse incentives.  For instance, let's say that KDA is a factor in your rating, and you're personally doing well in a match but your team is behind.  You might be encouraged to just let the enemy team push to victory rather than going all-out and dying a whole lot for that 5-10% chance to make a comeback.  It's **very** bad when you encourage players to do things that don't actually maximize their team's chances to win.

>Actually I described the actual system.

> Right now your LP gains and losses are mostly determined by your MMR relative to the division you are in.  I assumed you just wanted something like "gain 20LP per win, lose 20LP per loss."  If you meant something else you will need to clarify.

>Well, that's the problem: how to calculate a player performance. I guess that's what to be improved in the first place.

Some things are obvious, at least with everything else equal: dying is bad, killing enemies is good, missing CS is bad, taking objectives is good and losing them is bad.  But it very quickly becomes much more complicated.  Is it worth trading kills?  Or letting the enemy team take a dragon if you get one of their towers?  Should a support sacrifice themselves to save a teammate?  Should you give up CS to harass the enemy and maybe set up a kill?  How do you weigh objectives versus kills versus CS?

Even if you have answers for some of those, the problem is that once you start rating people not just on whether they win or lose but *how* they win or lose, you **will** change how people play.  Now, if you had a super-accurate rating system that could tease out individual contributions while being very hard to game, would it be a good thing?  Maybe.  But you'd need a much more detailed proposal than just "Riot should decide who did good and promote them".

As much as people whine about the vagaries of the current Ranked solo queue implementation, it is in some sense "optimal" with large enough sample sizes.  The highest-ranked players are the ones able to exert the most (positive)  influence on the outcome of a match.

The 'inflation'/'deflation' of an *individual's* MMR is not the same phenomenon as system-wide inflation/deflation.
The former uses the terms to describe gains and losses of an individual within a system, while the latter describes phenomena akin to the economic phenomena of the same names where the very value of the 'currency' in question undergoes substantial change.

Being placed with higher- or lower-ranked players may distort individual MMR values, but it will not produce MMR inflation/deflation of the sort being talked about here.

Now, there are some possible ways around this (such as adjusting the 'weight' of MMR changes in afk-affected games to account for the penalty) but that kind of added complexity can still cause things to go terribly wrong in the long-term if not implemented properly (and it can be very difficult to determine whether or not you have until that long-term actually happens).

"The 'inflation'/'deflation' of an individual's MMR is not the same phenomenon as system-wide inflation/deflation."

But this is what leads to system-wide inflation/deflation. A large scale system cannot change unless many small scale factors work in combination with each other repeatedly over a set course.

Low income neighborhoods near the city have high incarceration and arrest rates

System inflation/deflation can occur when the individual gains/losses are *unbalanced*.
Individual gains/losses, *in a balanced system* (where there is an equal loss for every gain), do not cause system inflation/deflation.
